titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Walter K. Fisher Journals

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit

did.head: Overview
did.abstract: Collection consists of his journals from field trips studying mammals and birds in northern California, Nevada, the Sierras, and the Mono Lake region, 1897-1901. There are narrative parts describing the country and the animals encountered, as well as lists of specimens and occasional sketches. The collection also includes one photograph of Fisher and a photocopy of a biographical piece by John Davis, 1958.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Walter K. Fisher Journals (SC0785). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: Walter K. Fisher was educated at Stanford University, earning 3 degrees in zoology: A.B. 1901, A.M. 1903, and Ph.D. 1906. He joined the Stanford faculty in 1902 as assistant in zoology, becoming an instructor in 1907, assistant professor in 1909, and professor of biology in 1925. He was Director of the Hopkins Marine Station from 1917 until his retirement in 1943. Although he specialized in invertebrates, he was also known for his work in ornithology.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of his journals from field trips studying mammals and birds in northern California, Nevada, the Sierras, and the Mono Lake region, 1897-1901. There are narrative parts describing the country and the animals encountered, as well as lists of specimens and occasional sketches. The collection also includes one photograph of Fisher and a photocopy of a biographical piece by John Davis, 1958.

did.unittitle: Journal 1897-98: summer trips studying mammals in California, Oregon and Washington, 1897, and in Nevada, 1898
Journal 1898-1901: notes from bird watching/collecting excursions in the Palo Alto and Santa Cruz Mountains area and the Lake Tahoe area, with some notes pertaining to plants
Loose items from the 1898-1901 journal: photograph (presumably of Fisher) and lists
Journal 1899: notes from mammal/bird collecting trip in summer of 1899 through northern California, with Prof. Dudley and others
Journal 1899: expanded version of notes from summer trip
Journal 1900: notes from summer excursion collecting birds and mammals from northeastern California working west [this trip not in the 1898-1901 journal]
Journal 1901: notes from excursions in Shasta County and the Mono Lake region [these trips not in the 1898-1901 journal]
Davis, John, "In Memoriam: Walter Kenrick Fisher" The Auk, Vol. 75 [photocopy]
